script.speaker: David
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, let's dive right into something that has always struck me as profoundly counterintuitive. The story of Adam and Eve's Fall in Genesis 3 seems like a devastating tragedy—they're cast out of paradise into pain, sorrow, and death, as described in Genesis 3:16–19. Yet the book of Moses transforms that entire narrative. How do we reconcile this apparent loss with the reality that it was essential for our eternal progression?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, that's a perfect place to begin, because the restored truths in Moses reveal the Fall not as an end but as the vital beginning of growth. Adam and Eve needed more than beautiful surroundings in Eden; they required opposition, choices, repentance, and the Savior's Atonement to progress toward becoming like God. What strikes me is Moses 5:9–12, where after leaving the garden, Adam blesses God, saying, 'I know not, save the Lord commanded me,' and Eve declares, 'Were it not for our transgression we never should have had seed, and never should have known good and evil, and the joy of our redemption, and the eternal life which God giveth unto all the obedient.' Their perspective shifts everything.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's fascinating—Adam and Eve themselves express gladness. It reminds me of 2 Nephi 2:19–25, where Lehi teaches that there must needs be opposition in all things for us to prove ourselves. Help me understand how this Fall sets up that opposition in God's plan.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly, David. Lehi explains in 2 Nephi 2:11 that God gave us agency to see if we would obey the commandments. Without the Fall, there would be no opposition—no misery to contrast joy, no wrong to appreciate right. The Fall introduced mortality's challenges, but precisely because of those, we can choose righteousness and access the Atonement.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I'm intrigued by how Moses 4 adds depth to Satan's role. In Moses 4:1–4, Satan seeks to destroy agency by deceiving Eve without allowing consequences. What protected our agency there?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Heavenly Father and Jesus Christ preserved it. Moses 4:3 states, 'Wherefore, because that Satan rebelled against me, and sought to destroy the agency of man, which I, the Lord God, had given him, and also, that I should give unto him mine own power; by the power of mine Only Begotten, I caused that he should be cast down.' This shows divine intervention ensuring we could choose freely, just as Elder Dale G. Renlund taught that God's parenting goal is for us to choose righteousness and become like Him.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That protection of agency is profound. Now, looking at Genesis 3:1–7 and Moses 4:22–31, the immediate results of the Fall seem harsh—pain in childbirth, toil in labor, dust to dust. How does Moses 5:4–15 turn that into hope?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: By revealing God's redemptive plan right away. An angel appears to Adam and Eve, teaching them the gospel. In Moses 5:10–11, they learn of the Savior: 'And Adam and Eve, his wife, ceased not to call upon God. And Adam knew Eve his wife, and she conceived and bare Cain, and said: I have gotten a man from the Lord; wherefore he may not reject his words. But behold, also Cain hearkened not, saying: Who is the Lord, that I should obey his voice and hearken unto his commandments, and who is Abel, that I should be his servant?' Wait, no—that's later. Earlier, Moses 5:6–7: 'And Adam and Eve, his wife, called upon the name of the Lord, and they heard the voice of the Lord from the way toward the Garden of Eden, speaking unto them, and they saw him not; for they were shut out from his presence. And he gave unto them commandments.' Then the angel explains sacrifice pointing to Christ.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, and Moses 5:11 captures their joy: 'And Eve, his wife, heard all these things and was glad, saying: Were it not for our transgression we never should have had seed, and never should have known good and evil, and the joy of our redemption, and the eternal life which God giveth unto all the obedient.' They were glad! This reframes the Fall entirely.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Precisely. It's not regret but gratitude. Now, consider a detail often missed: Genesis 3:16 and Moses 4:22, where the Lord says to Eve, 'thy desire shall be to thy husband, and he shall rule over thee.' This has been misinterpreted as justification for unkindness, but modern prophets clarify husbands and wives as equal partners.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Right, like in 'The Family: A Proclamation to the World.' Elder Dale G. Renlund describes a righteous husband as one who ministers, acknowledges errors, offers praise, and treats his wife with utmost respect. What does 'rule over' truly mean in context?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: It reflects protective stewardship in a fallen world, not dominance. Elder Ulisses Soares teaches equal partnership in marriage, where both fulfill divine roles collaboratively. This ties back to the Fall's necessities—facing opposition together strengthens eternal families.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's a meaningful connection. Shifting to opposition's role, 2 Nephi 2:27 says, 'men are free according to the flesh; and all things are given them which are expedient unto man. And they are free to choose liberty and eternal life, through the great Mediator of all men, or to choose captivity and death, according to the captivity and power of the devil.' How does the Fall enable this freedom?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Without the Fall, Adam and Eve remained in innocence but static—no progression. Entering mortality brought agency into action. Dallin H. Oaks' 'Opposition in All Things' reinforces that opposition is essential for growth, mirroring Lehi's teachings.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Now, Satan doesn't stop. In Moses 4:4–12 and 5:13–33, he tempts Adam, Eve, and their children similarly today—deceiving to blind us. How does Heavenly Father counter that?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Through commandments, the Holy Ghost, and covenants. Notice Moses 4:13–16, 27: After the Fall, Adam and Eve sew fig leaves to cover nakedness, but the Lord God clothes them with skins: 'Unto Adam, and also unto his wife, did I, the Lord God, make coats of skins, and clothed them.' Nakedness symbolizes spiritual vulnerability; clothing represents divine covering through covenants.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I hadn't connected that so directly. Revelation 7:9, 13–15 describes the redeemed in white robes; 2 Nephi 9:14 warns of nakedness at judgment without atonement. This points to temple garments, doesn't it?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, profoundly. For those endowed, Adam and Eve's experience illuminates the garment's significance as a reminder of covenants and protection. It's God's way of clothing us spiritually amid opposition.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Remarkable. Let's explore sacrifices in Moses 5:4–9, 16–26. Adam obeys without understanding, yet God accepts it. Abel offers with real intent; Cain does not. Why the difference?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Attitude matters. Moses 5:21: 'And Abel hearkened unto the voice of the Lord. And Abel was a keeper of sheep, but Cain was a tiller of the ground.' Abel's was acceptable because of his willing heart; Cain's lacked obedience. This prefigures Christ's sacrifice—we must offer ourselves with full purpose.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That transforms how I view personal sacrifices today. What patterns emerge across dispensations here?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: A divine consistency: agency protected in premortality (Moses 4:1–4), exercised post-Fall (Moses 5), taught by prophets like Lehi (2 Nephi 2), and affirmed today in For the Strength of Youth's call to make inspired choices. It's eternal progression through opposition.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I'm seeing how Mosiah 3:19 fits: 'For the natural man is an enemy to God... unless he yields to the enticings of the Holy Spirit.' The Fall makes us 'natural,' but redemption naturalizes us to God.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Beautifully said. Alma 12:21–37 expands on probationary time post-Fall, emphasizing repentance. Doctrine and Covenants 29:39–43 outlines the Fall's purpose: 'to bring about his eternal purposes... they would have had no joy, for they knew no misery.' Multi-layered divine design.

script.speaker: David
script.text: From a historical lens, what cultural insights illuminate Adam and Eve's experience?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Ancient Near Eastern views saw gardens as divine realms, expulsion as loss of immortality. But Moses reveals purpose—seed-bearing, knowledge of good/evil leading to redemption. Archaeological parallels in Mesopotamian myths show creation-fall motifs, but ours uniquely emphasizes growth through Christ.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That makes ancient events vivid. How does this resolve the initial tragedy?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: By focusing on possibilities: glory received outweighs paradise lost. Adam and Eve's gladness in Moses 5 models our response to mortality's trials.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Now, hidden connections: the angel's gospel lesson in Moses 5:4–15 links directly to temple ordinances, sacrifices symbolizing Christ.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, and Cain's rejection in Moses 5:13–33 warns of Satan's ongoing deceptions—pride, misplaced offerings. Abel's acceptance shows obedience's power across generations.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Connecting to today, how do these ancient patterns shape modern discipleship?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: They remind us to choose agency daily, resist deception via scriptures and prayer, honor covenants as divine clothing, offer sacrifices willingly—like time, pride, or will to God.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Elder Renlund's emphasis on choosing right resonates. In families, equal partnership mirrors Adam and Eve's unity amid opposition.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Absolutely. Husbands ruling with respect fosters eternal progression together, as in the Proclamation.

script.speaker: David
script.text: What about Satan's tactics in Moses 4:4–12—bold lies like 'Ye shall not surely die' or 'your eyes shall be opened.' Same today?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Undeniably. He blinds with half-truths, tempts with immediate gratification. Heavenly Father's help: commandments, Atonement, prophets.

script.speaker: David
script.text: This deepens my appreciation for the plan. One more layer: how does the Fall integrate with the plan of salvation?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: It's the bridge from innocence to exaltation. Premortal agency, mortal probation via Fall, postmortal redemption—all converging on Christ. As 2 Nephi 2:25 states, 'Adam fell that men might be; and men are, that they might have joy.'

script.speaker: David
script.text: Profound. Modern revelation builds seamlessly—President Nelson's teachings on covenants reflect this pattern of progression.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: They do. Covenants 'clothe' us, enabling choices leading to eternal life.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, as we wrap up, what invitation would you extend based on these discoveries?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Ponder your own 'Fall' moments—trials as opposition for growth. List ways Satan tempts you, then counter with God's protections: agency, Atonement, covenants. Like Adam and Eve, find joy in redemption.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Excellent. Search Genesis 3, Moses 4–5 personally, marking Fall's results and God's remedies. Let it transform regret into gratitude.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And discuss in families how opposition builds eternal families through equal partnership.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Thanks, Sarah, for these insights. Listeners, apply these truths this week. Until next time, keep studying.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Thanks, David. God bless your studies.
